review_title: It was great working as a TA
pros: I was a TA for 6 months for Statistics and Personnel Psychology. It was a great experience. I had a lot of flexibility while working there. The professors were very supportive.
cons: According to me there was no downside while working in this position.

pros: Flexibility around schedules and lifestyles.
cons: Internal politics detract from progressive work

pros: people are friendly and helpful
cons: not a whole lot, pay could be better for some positions

pros: Good people and the students are great
cons: Not so Diverse in leadership

review_title: Terrible leadership and unethical practices causing turnover
pros:
Excellent PTO and insurance 
Tuition reimbursement 
Professional development reimbursement
cons:
TCS is a for profit disguised as a non for profit institution. Admissions’ main focus is admitting as many students as possible and not considering whether a student is a good fit for the school or not. 

Leadership actively discriminates against POC and will either push them out or fire them. Leadership will make overtly discriminatory and inappropriate statements and when reported, nothing is done and leadership continues to engage in discriminatory behavior. Leadership is more concerned with having complacent employees who will do as they are told whether it is ethical or not and have no problem scapegoating employees for their own errors. Turnover is mostly due to poor leadership with new employees quitting within a few months - yet no one conducts exit interviews to continue to not hold leadership accountable for how they treat their team. 

Professors are expected to pass students even when students do not submit quality work or engage unprofessional behavior which is inappropriate to be in the field of psychology. Staff has to appease students even when students are in the wrong and no one is held accountable. 

TCS is on track to be the next Argosy, especially as they’ve hired former Argosy leadership who brought the same unethical practices to TCS and continue to hire individuals who will be “yes men” rather than those who will improve what TCS needs to improve.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Students are great and they get a good education. Faculty deliever that in spite of employee morale that could not get lower.
cons: Management (there is no leadership). The current president started here as a student and never left. Has no credentials for the job. Money is all that matters. Earlier review wondered if leadership knows what they are doing. They do not. Reviewer also wondered if the school would be around in 10 years. I give it 3 years, tops.

pros: The building is modern and new.
cons: No training, bad manager on the verge of sexual harassment

pros: Location is great and accessible.

pros: Solid environment, room to advance and fun people
cons: Pay, unrealistic goals, red tape can be a problem

pros: Faculty colleagues are very dedicated to students and teaching.
cons: The administration is anti-faculty and year over year increase workload for faculty.

pros: Easy to get a job, friendly co-workers, nice benefits, flexible start time/remote.
cons: No personal boundaries, will add more and more work over time without compensation or support, does not provide cross training at higher levels, does not respect employees without MA or Doctoral level degrees. Values faculty over staff. Revolving door of employment at mid and higher levels.

pros: Relationship among colleagues was positive and supportive.
cons: Salary for Full time faculty is below national average for online education

pros: People, students, location, programs, career

job_title: Department Chair in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
+ APA accredited.
+ Part of a larger educational system called The Chicago Educational System.
+ The CEO, Michael Horowitz, of the Chicago education system pays himself handsomely. He is one of the highest paid college presidents in the country and pays himself millions of dollars EVERY YEAR running a so-called NOT-FOR-PROFIT. 
+ If you want to see what happens when you let psychologists run amok, check this place out. IT’S CRAZY HERE and the “hilarity” ensues.
cons:
- High turnover of staff. Most don’t last more than a year. Those who remain are willing to be abused by management.
- Constant vacant positions means you will have to pick up the slack to make the place work. Staff are overworked and sick.
- Mean-spirited senior leadership. They like to create a culture of fear to motivate employees. People are taken out without warning. Senior leaders, e.g., Deans, can be let go without explanation or warning. Sort of a “let that be a lesson to the rest of you” creating a culture of fear because you could be next. Lots of layoffs too. Mostly in the Fall. Be warned!
- Bureaucratic to the Nth degree. Every department has forms to fill out and cc’s and blind cc’s everyone to cover their behinds out of fear of retribution.
- Focus is solely on sales and not quality of education. Every meeting is about how to get more students in the door. Never a peep about improving things unless it is about getting more students in the door.
Low budget atmosphere. 
- Hypocritical culture. The president, Michelle Nelson, who is rarely seen, promotes mental health outside the school (and mostly her image), yet the environment is toxic with high turnover, siloed, lack of cooperation.
- Low pay makes it difficult to recruit adjuncts and staff.
- Career opportunities are limited. Very siloed so you can’t move around.
- HR is mostly inept except when taking people out. They excel at that.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: Loved the ABA department, more than the school
pros: Colleagues, flexibility in research topics

pros: It was great working with the faculty and staff.
cons: There is no room for growth.

pros: Enjoyed working with students and faculty.

pros: The organization is focused on development and expansion and there are opportunities for you to evolve your role in the organization. Fiscal responsibility is prioritized which makes for stability, if not large increases in compensation. Pay is pretty good for higher education and the benefits are average with a more generous retirement fund policy.
cons: Your experience will very much depend on your manager and there doesn't seem to be an overall push to set standards around organizational culture. Work-life boundaries are an issue that requires vigilance from the employee to enforce.

review_title: Really enjoyed working there. reasonable workload and we're very flexible with accommodating my needs as a student.

review_title: A Great Organization with Great People

cons: Can sometimes be difficult to get to know other members of the organization due to remote operations, especially in other states, but virtual social events definitely help.

- Fast paced environment, entrepreneurial mindset that allows one to continuously explore and invent/improve systems and processes.

- Flexible schedule as long as the work was done.
cons: If you're not looking for an accelerated career advancement, widespread career exposure and a place where you can constantly put your skills to the test, this may not be the place for you.  I had a mentor that really put me through bootcamp, but as I reflect over the years, I am so thankful of how far and how fast I've grown.

pros: Most employees from Dean Academic Affairs and lower are some of the most down to earth, talented, real people.
cons: Definitely CANNOT say the same thing about Campus Deans and up. Talk about snakes...I'm pretty sure these people are in an evil cult. I think the President thinks she's the queen of the world. Her cabinet members are her minions; they didn't get into those roles because of the innovative thinking they bring to the table, that's for sure. And her HR guy is her puppet - she wants someone gone? He makes them go away. They've lost anyone who was worth a lick in HR, too. Who am I kidding? ANYONE who comes to work here and has half a brain will leave PDQ. It doesn't take long to see the truth of the dysfunction that exists.

pros: Friendly and generally supportive environment, convenient location, interesting and varied work. Students are great and eager to learn. Excellent benefits, vacation time, sick time, insurance options, 403(b) matching, summer hours. Part-time employees get some benefits. Monthly company socials with alcohol and free food. Campus leadership is fairly connected and visible to the campus, but school-wide leadership is very disconnected.
cons: VERY low pay (think 10%-20% below market value in Chicago). Laughably huge and pretty insulting disconnect between leadership and daily ops. Huge staff/faculty divide. Demands of the job much higher than the pay. Cutting many benefits like no more bonuses but merit increases capped at 3%, and nobody gets a 3% merit increase. Getting less non-profit and more for-profit and becoming more bureaucratic every semester. Communication within departments is spotty and inter-departmental communication almost nothing.

pros: The insurance and 403b is outstanding.
cons: The leadership team needs serious revamping. It begins at the President and funnels down. Poor team work. The leadership team makes one feel very welcomed and then they suck you dry. They do not care who  you are or what you have done for them- they will use you and throw you away. Unlike state schools, they will make you work on campus 5-6 days per week and act as if they own you. Extremely unethical individuals working . Wasn’t paid on time on several occasions and they make no effort to compensate you for it. Overcharge students and accept anyone that applies. Degree mill. Lost very good colleagues over the 10+ years of working there due to unreasonable moves. If you play the politics game and love it then this is the place for you.

pros: The students are great.  I really loved working with such a passionate, energetic group of people.  Faculty colleagues were also wonderful.  They were very dedicated and hard working.
cons: Starting with the top level of leadership, I don't the school was run with a lot of integrity.  Top leadership appeared to be a revolving door, which led to a lot of initiatives being dropped near completion, a lot of work lost, and a lot of frustration for the people doing the work.

review_title: A For-Profit Masquerading as a Non-Profit
pros: TCSPP is a regionally accredited institution - for now.
cons: I did not detect a serious interest in the well-being or development of students.  Instead, there was a serious interest in "retaining" students.  Administrators run TCS like a corporation.  Faculty members have little or no influence on how teaching actually happens. Faculty are broken into numerous categories to divide the faculty.  Faculty are not invited to join a faculty senate or any similar body.  Department faculty meetings focus on "numbers", rather than on real issues.  Many faculty members, and the president, are former graduates.  About 50% of the people who work at TCS are graduates of TCS. That means that a lot of them are used to the non-academic atmosphere and are completely unmotivated to move the institution in a positive direction. They think that things are fine.

review_title: Don't appreciate their employees or pay them what they're worth
pros: Some of the people are really great at the Los Angeles campus. They have a 403B and invest 7% for you, which is great!
cons:
They don't pay employees (not including upper management) enough for all they ask them to do. Upper management does not have a strong leader that trusts the employees under them. The policies change weekly it seems. I was told numerous times that certain things would happen to increase my salary, none of which ever happened.

I did the work of probably 3 people and was not compensated appropriately, or appreciated quite frankly. My salary was around $15K lower than what people in my position make at other companies.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Many of the staff and faculty are great to work with and they are passionate about what they do. The PTO plan is great, as long as you work with a manager that will grant you time off.
cons: First, I just want to say that I left on good terms. I would take one of the previous review with a grain of salt, as I do not feel it is honest. These reviews are anonymous, so it's hard to know if they are being left by those that were let go, or who left on their own. I can say with certainty, however, that the majority of staff and faculty are not happy at The Chicago School of Professional Psychology. The previous review also states that the PTO plan is great, but they state they are a faculty member. Faculty doesn't receive any PTO, so my guess is it was a review by someone in upper management meaning to mislead. Leadership is terrible and it starts at the very top. There is no transparency and they purposely mislead and manipulate people. If you have any integrity, you will be let go. If anyone challenges the president or certain members of the Executive Cabinet, they will be let go. I saw so many great colleagues that were let go because they stood up for their morals and principles. I wholeheartedly believe that the president does not care about the students or the staff/faculty; all she cares about is money and expanding. If you are reading these reviews before applying or accepting a position, please do understand that these reviews truly do represent the way that people feel about the culture at The Chicago School. I wish I could recommend it as a place to work, but it is a very toxic culture and only those that show their "loyalty" to the president stay.

review_title: Dedication to diversity and community outreach. Great benefits
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
This is a very fast-paced work environment that's often seeking to grow and constantly improve. If you're someone who is inflexible or unwilling to do what it takes to accomplish tasks, you might have a hard time. 

There are great benefits, including 7% 403b giving (no match necessary), only 7.5 hour workday, summer hours, and educational/professional training if you want it. 

The school is very dedicated to diversity (students, faculty, staff) and is focused on community outreach and service work. The students are passionate and intelligent.
cons: Sometimes too many initiatives are taken on too quickly, and it can be hard to give each one the attention it deserves to be successful.

job_title: Program Chair in Los Angeles, CA
pros: No much.  Some good faculty.
cons: The most insane, dysfunction and toxic environment that I've ever worked in.  This is a shell-game for the Ed System.  Horrible President who has created a culture of fear.  She has hired people who create the textbook definition of a hostile work environment.  Even a "Beverly Leslie" personality who continually creates abuse and drama.  Pushed out all minority leadership.  Leave it to psychologists to create the sickest environment.  CONSTANT TURNOVER.  All about the numbers and ridiculous control processes.  This is a for-profit masquerading as a non-profit.  Ridiculously expensive.  Everyone I know is looking for another job. Worse job I ever had.

pros:
The 401k contribution is nice, and there are some great people that work there. There is also a free gym membership. 

When I joined The Chicago School I had hope this would be a positive experience, unfortunately it was anything but.
cons: The organization is run by a small group of people that lack the knowledge and experience necessary to effectively run the organization; from a business perspective, and from an organizational culture perspective. The turnover is incredibly high from the leadership level, all the way down. There is no work life balance; you are expected to be on call in the evenings and weekends. The college is partnered with TCS Education System, which has similar issues from the top down.

pros: Quite simply the best organization I have ever worked for. An outstanding administration that does not tolerate low and poor performance.  The negative reviews are from those that got termed for poor performance. This place is simply amazing.  You get over a month of paid time off when you start working here.  The President is the best leader.
cons: No cons to report. Any negative reviews are from those that were terminated for poor performance.  The best people are always retained.

pros: I really enjoyed how close I currently am located to the chicago school. Despite it being in a great location, i was really able to excel in the programs.
cons: I wish I would have chosen to attend TCSPP before spending so much money on an out of state private college during my first year of teaching going back and forth.

pros: Good benefits package helps offset below average salaries. Staff are mostly nice folks but silos remain embedded creating a second class staff which even HR forgets to disclose to new hires.
cons: Faculty/Management are unnecessarily petty, constantly shifting priorities and plan. Strategies come and go. The only consistent investment is at the executive level. Money allocated for professional development only reaches faculty. Staff funds get reallocated to cover budget shortfalls, because they constantly budget for unrealistic enrollment goals.

pros: Good work-life balance, flexibility, relatively low stress,
cons: Sometimes it can be a "What have you done for me lately environment" although I think this is true of most admissions roles.  I do like it better than working in for-profit.  The admissions standards for students are fairly rigorous compared to for-profits which seems like everyone can get in

review_title: A challenging environment in mostly good ways striving to do the right things well
pros: Intellectual stimulation, sincere faculty, appreciative students, some flexibility, and a nice River North campus are the best parts of this organization. This organization strives to do right by all its stakeholders.
cons: Too much bureaucracy combined with a lot of student needs and demanding curriculum make for a difficult and less than predictable workload at times.

pros: There are none.  It is just a nightmare.  See my comments in cons.
cons:
The Chicago School of Professional Psychology (TCSPP) is a shell game solely directed by Michael Horowitz of the TCS Ed System (highest pay education executive in the U.S.) when “member school” (TCSPP is a member school) pay exorbitated fees to Ed System in direct violating while the Ed System directs the actives of these schools in direct violation of U.S. nonprofit law. It is an illegal shell game that is being reported to the regional-accrediting authority. The Chicago School to masquerades as a nonprofit when in fact it functions as vulture for-profit -- the true legacy of Education Corporation of America, Argosy, Corinthian, Kaplan, TT Tech (and so many others), and let’s not forget Trump University. 
 
Leadership is inept and vicious – just look no further than it’s president Michelle Woods. Turnover is on the level of Trump’s Cabinet. Good people figure out the scam in about a year and leave. 
 
All applicant students are accepted regardless of their abilities to succeed racking up thousands and thousands of dollars in Federal student loan debt.  Student attrition is record high with enormous numbers of students failing out after two semesters (but what the heck, the school got their tuition and fees for the two courses and there are lots more desperate potential students to exploit). Tuition is ridiculously high and many, many graduates leaving with over $100,000+ in debt and virtually NO job prospects.  This is the current day sub-prime mortgage scheme of 10 years ago.
 
Advice to prospective students: there are many other greater schools (including state schools) which will offer you a much better education at a fraction of the price.  Further, they have career services that will help you find a job.  
 
Advice to prospective faculty: have a conscience, this is immoral. 
 
BTW, the creation of the gloating reviews above is tasked to a staff person at the TCS Ed System’s marketing department who submits those reviews from the different IP addresses.

pros: Fair compensation for higher ed, plenty of professional development opportunities, friendly work environment, great benefits!
cons:
--Poor technology. Their IT team is solid but they need to have the funding to update and improve systems. 
--Disorganized reporting system. Need clearer departments and reporting structures.
